channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israel-Hamas War: Israel Will Press On in Gaza, Netanyahu Says, as Troops Advance
item.description: In a news conference, Israel’s prime minister said that “calls for a cease-fire are calls for Israel to surrender to Hamas.” He asked nations to back Israel in its fight.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke rising after an Israeli airstrike in Gaza on Sunday.

item.title: Near an Acapulco Beach: Food, Water and Prayer After Hurricane Otis
item.description: Dozens of displaced locals gathered in a converted shelter, waiting for resources to be delivered to their ravaged city.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:credit: David Guzmán/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: People gathering outside a church in Acapulco, Mexico, on Sunday. Inside, dozens of people dozed and the supply of water was running low.

item.title: Riot in Dagestan as Mob Storms Airport Looking for Israeli Passengers
item.description: A mob in the Russian republic of Dagestan stormed runways looking for a flight carrying Jewish passengers. The episode highlighted the threat of ethnic strife in Russia.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: @askrasul, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: ‘A Very Slow Game:’ Why the Pace of Israel’s Ground Operation Counts
item.description: Israel’s invasion of Gaza is proceeding more slowly than expected. That may suit the needs of its allies — and its adversaries, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: A pro-Palestinian rally in New York City on Saturday.

item.title: A Leaning Tower in Italy (Not Pisa) Becomes a Worry
item.description: City officials in Bologna have closed a city-center square as they study what to do about the Garisenda Tower. A solution could take years.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:credit: Susan Wright for The New York Times
item.media:description: Recent surveys of the Garisenda Tower, left of the much taller Asinelli Tower in Bologna, Italy, have found traces of unexpected rotation in its incline.

item.title: Afghans Leaving Pakistan Ahead of Ultimatum
item.description: More than 70,000 undocumented Afghans have returned home in recent weeks to meet a Wednesday deadline ordered by the Pakistani government.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Safiullah Padshah and Elise Blanchard
item.media:credit: Elise Blanchard for The New York Times

item.title: Both Sides Pay a Bloody Price for Coveted Ukrainian City
item.description: The fight for the battered city of Avdiivka has emerged this fall as the fiercest battle of the war. Waves of Russian assaults have not broken through so far.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Nicole Tung
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times

item.title: FIFA Bans Luis Rubiales, Former Soccer Chief in Spain, for 3 Years
item.description: Luis Rubiales, who led the country’s soccer federation, departed in disgrace after he forcibly kissed a player after the Women’s World Cup final.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd and Tariq Panja
item.media:credit: Manu Fernandez/Associated Press
item.media:description: Luis Rubiales in Madrid last August with members of Spain’s women’s soccer team after their victory in the World Cup.

item.title: In Kenya, King Charles Will ‘Walk a Tightrope’ on Britain’s Past
item.description: More candid than his mother, he is likely to acknowledge the monarchy’s brutal colonial history but avoid inviting calls for reparations.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Camilla, Queen Consort of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Aaron Chown
item.media:description: King Charles III and Queen Camilla at a reception at Buckingham Palace on Oct. 24, viewing objects from the Royal Collection. On their visit to Kenya next week, palace officials said, King Charles “would acknowledge the more painful aspects of the U.K. and Kenya’s shared history.”

item.title: They Refused to Serve. Now They’re Supporting Israel’s War Effort.
item.description: The Brothers in Arms group helped lead protests against the government, with members vowing to ignore military call-ups. But after the Hamas attacks, it pivoted to aid those affected by the conflict.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Natan Odenheimer
item.media:credit: Ohad Zwigenberg/Associated Press
item.media:description: A donation center in Tel Aviv run by the Brothers in Arms group. Hundreds of volunteers with the organization work computers and phones to figure out how to ship supplies to where they are needed.

item.title: In Ukraine, 3 Childhood Friends Became Brothers in War Against Russia
item.description: Three friends met as boys in western Ukraine. When Russia invaded, they enlisted in the same unit. There was comfort, and dread, in serving together.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia

item.title: The Rigid World of French Cheesemaking Meets Unbound Climate Change
item.description: Reams of rules govern how the best French cheeses are made, but hotter, drier summers may unshackle struggling producers.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hervé Barnier and his wife, Hélène Barnier, with their goats grazing at Ferme de Pracoutel near Vesc, France.

item.title: Itaewon Halloween Celebrations Subdued a Year After Tragedy
item.description: The authorities in Seoul were out in force over the weekend, but the crowds in the typically bustling neighborhood were sparse.
item.dc:creator: Chang W. Lee and Inyoung Kang
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The increased police presence was visible on Saturday in Itaewon, the Seoul neighborhood where a year ago a crowd crush in a narrow alley killed nearly 160 people.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Israel advances on Gaza City.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli artillery position near the border with Gaza yesterday.

item.title: Hochul Visits Cornell to Reassure Jewish Students Rattled by Online Threats
item.description: “I want them to know they are not alone,” New York’s governor said of the students, after posts on a student forum called for violence against Jews.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Maag
item.media:credit: David Bauder/Associated Press
item.media:description: The state police on guard at the Center for Jewish Living at Cornell University on Monday after online threats.

item.title: Famed Iranian Rights Lawyer Reportedly Jailed and Beaten
item.description: Nasrin Sotoudeh was one of several activists arrested at the funeral of Armita Geravand, a 16-year-old girl who died after not wearing a head covering in public, in a case that drew parallels to that of Mahsa Amini.
item.dc:creator: Leily Nikounazar
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Abedin Taherkenareh/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Nasrin Sotoudeh, a lawyer and human rights activist, at her house in Tehran, Iran, in 2013.

item.title: Israel announces the first rescue of a soldier abducted on Oct. 7, a 19-year-old woman.
item.description: She was abducted after Hamas gunmen overran and briefly captured a military base in Nahal Oz, just east of the northern Gaza Strip.
item.dc:creator: Johnatan Reiss and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Israel Security Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: Private Ori Megidish, center, celebrating on Monday after being rescued from captivity in Gaza.

item.title: ‘Friends’ Cast Release Statement on Matthew Perry’s Death
item.description: Perry, who portrayed Chandler Bing, died on Saturday. He was 54.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Warner Bros. Television, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Matthew Perry, third from right, with his “Friends” castmates: From left, David Schwimmer, Courteney Cox, Jennifer Aniston, Matt LeBlanc and Lisa Kudrow.

item.title: Bloomberg and 34,000 Donors Combine to Give $88 Million to Israel Medical Service
item.description: The former New York City mayor and billionaire philanthropist said he would match $44 million in donations from nearly 34,000 people.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer
item.media:credit: Bennett Raglin/Getty Images
item.media:description: Michael Bloomberg at a 2016 gala for the American Friends of Magen David Adom.

item.title: Settler Violence Rising Against Palestinians in the West Bank
item.description: More than 100 Palestinians have been killed, more than 2,000 injured and nearly 1,000 forcibly displaced by Israeli settlers since Hamas’s Oct. 7 attacks on Israel, the United Nations said.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Rami Nazzal
item.media:credit: Thomas Coex/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Damaged properties last week at the West Bank village of Wadi al-Siq. Representatives of a community of 200 Bedouin herders living there said that Jewish settlers, accompanied by police officers and Israeli soldiers, had attacked the village on Oct. 12.

item.title: Gazans, as Bombs Fall, Say Escape Is Impossible
item.description: As bombs fell in the background, Palestinians in the Hamas-ruled territory recounted a struggle to survive.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Abu Bakr Bashir and Iyad Abuheweila
item.media:credit: Mohammed Saber/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Palestinians walking among the rubble in the Tel al-Hawa neighborhood of Gaza City on Monday.

item.title: Democratic Rifts Over Israel Burst to the Forefront in Congress
item.description: The divisions are erupting as the House weighs a G.O.P. bid to censure the only Palestinian-American member of Congress for criticizing Israel and votes on a large aid bill to back Israel in the war in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Democrats are openly at odds as Congress is set to tackle sweeping emergency spending legislation to address the ongoing conflict in Gaza.

item.title: Netanyahu Rejects Calls for a Cease-fire Against Hamas in Gaza
item.description: Israel’s prime minister adopted a defiant tone in a rare news briefing, saying that the country would not agree to a halt in attacks because, he argued, doing so would strengthen Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Abir Sultan/EPA, via Shutterstock

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Israeli Forces Advance on Gaza City
item.description: Plus we remember Matthew Perry.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli tank, seen from Sderot, operating in Gaza on Monday.

item.title: Biden’s Support for Israel Now Comes With Words of Caution
item.description: The administration has become more critical of Israel’s response to the Hamas attacks, a shift that U.S. officials attribute to the humanitarian crisis in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear, David E. Sanger and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The change in President Biden’s tone has occurred against the backdrop of global denunciations of Israel’s actions and an explosion of divisive protests in the United States.

item.title: Israelis Advance on Gaza City, as Netanyahu Rules Out Cease-Fire
item.description: Israel’s leaders vowed to destroy Hamas, which controls the Gaza Strip, after the deadly Oct. 7 attack, and Israeli ground forces are closing in on the city from three directions.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner, Lauren Leatherby, Vivian Yee and Aaron Boxerman
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli artillery position near the border with Gaza on Monday.

item.title: Israel Shrouds Gaza Invasion in Secrecy
item.description: After an air campaign that killed thousands of Palestinians, Israel has begun a ground assault, but it took hours for outside observers to understand what was happening. The ambiguity was intentional.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli tank, seen from Israel, operating in Gaza on Monday.

item.title: Shani Louk, Believed Kidnapped by Hamas, Was Likely Dead When She Was Taken, Family Says
item.description: Shortly after the Oct. 7 attacks, Hamas released a video showing a woman lying face down and mostly naked in the back of a pickup truck. Ms. Louk’s mother said the woman was likely her daughter.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola, Gabby Sobelman and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Ammar Awad/Reuters
item.media:description: A picture of Shani Louk at a demonstration held on Saturday in Tel Aviv by family members and supporters of the hostages who were taken on Oct. 7.

item.title: Wanda Poltawska, 101, Who Forged a Friendship With a Future Pope, Dies
item.description: She survived gruesome medical experimentation at the Ravensbrück concentration camp to become a psychiatrist — counseled by the priest who would become John Paul II.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden
item.media:credit: Eustachy Kossakowski
item.media:description: It was a contact in a confessional that first brought Dr. Poltawska together with a dynamic young parish priest, the Rev. Karol Wojtyla.

item.title: Carbon Emissions Budget to Hit Paris Accord Goals Is Now Smaller
item.description: Limiting warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius would be harder than ever, new calculations show, but less ambitious targets are still in reach.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Patrick Pleul/DPA, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The most promising paths for avoiding 1.5 degrees of warming are clearly gone, said one climate scientist.

item.title: Energy Dept. Pours Billions Into Electric Grids
item.description: America’s electric grids may need to expand by two-thirds by 2035 to handle future growth in clean energy, the agency said. The nation isn’t on track.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Jamil Baldwin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Parts for transmission lines awaiting installation Southern California.

item.title: Meta Will Charge up to €12.99 for Ad-Free Versions of Facebook and Instagram in Europe
item.description: Starting in November, subscriptions will cost between 9.99 euros and 12.99 euros per month, the company said.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano and Christine Hauser
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: Meta’s new pricing model for users in the European Union will range from €9.99 to €12.99 a month.

item.title: Middle East War Could Cause Oil Price Shock, World Bank Warns
item.description: A new report outlined how a major escalation of the conflict between Israel and Hamas could fuel a new bout of inflation.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Richard Carson/Reuters
item.media:description: An oil storage tank and crude oil pipeline at the Strategic Petroleum Reserve in Texas. The United States also tapped into the reserve last year to ease oil price pressures.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: Israel is ‘expanding’ ground operations in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Israeli military said on Sunday that its forces “continue to expand ground activities” in Gaza, and that it had hit 450 Hamas military targets over the past day.

item.title: Cornell Jewish Center Under Guard After Online Threats to Jewish Students
item.description: “We will not tolerate antisemitism at Cornell,” the university president said after threats were made against the Center for Jewish Living.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Maag
item.media:credit: Heather Ainsworth for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cornell University in April. Online posts on Sunday threatened violence against Jewish students there.

item.title: War Through the Eyes of Gaza’s Children
item.description: At a U.N. camp in southern Gaza, children have been forced to flee their homes and live in squalid conditions while trying to make sense of a war with no end in sight.
item.dc:creator: Mona El-Naggar, Neil Collier, Danielle Miller and Mark Boyer
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency

item.title: Mob Storms Plane Arriving From Israel at Russian Airport, Authorities Say
item.description: The Russian authorities announced that the airport in Makhachkala, the capital of the predominantly Muslim Dagestan region, was temporarily closed and riot police were dispatched to the scene.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko, Marc Santora, Isabel Kershner and Riley Mellen
item.media:credit: Reuters

item.title: How Years of Israeli Failures on Hamas Led to a Devastating Attack
item.description: Israeli officials completely underestimated the magnitude of the Oct. 7 attacks by Hamas, shattering the country’s once invincible sense of security.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Mark Mazzetti and Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Before the attack by Hamas on Oct. 7, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and top Israeli security officials believed the greatest threats to Israel were Iran and Hezbollah.

item.title: Monday Briefing: Israel Extends Gaza Ground Campaign
item.description: Plus as the world ages, Africa blooms with youth.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israel Defense Forces military near Israel-Gaza border near Sderot on Sunday.

item.title: For Israel's Netanyahu, War in Gaza and at Home
item.description: Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, apologized for accusing military and security officials of lapses that led to the Hamas massacre but declined to accept responsibility himself.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Abir Sultan
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu at a news conference at a military base in Tel Aviv on Saturday.

item.title: Gaza Blackout Cut Palestinians’ Internet and Phone Service for 34 Hours
item.description: As Israeli forces entered Gaza on Friday to fight Hamas, phone and internet service was severed, sowing chaos for Palestinian civilians and leaving rescuers driving blindly toward explosions.
item.dc:creator: Abu Bakr Bashir, Iyad Abuheweila, Vivian Nereim and Yousur Al-Hlou
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gazans line up at a bakery in Khan Younis, southern Gaza Strip on Friday.

item.title: Colombia Troops Search for Liverpool Star Luis Diaz’s Kidnapped Father
item.description: The parents of Luis Díaz, a Colombian star of the English club, were both kidnapped on Saturday. His mother was rescued hours later, but his father remains missing.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Colombia’s National Police, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Colombian authorities announced a reward of 200 million pesos, about $48,000, for any information that would help locate Luis Díaz’s father, Luis Manuel Díaz.

item.title: Nazis in Canada? A Secret List With Answers May Soon Be Released.
item.description: A report from an inquiry into possible war criminals in Canada has been kept from the public for almost 40 years.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Patrick Doyle/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: During a visit by President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine to Canada in September, Parliament honored Yaroslav Hunka, a Ukrainian-Canadian man who volunteered for a Nazi combat group.

item.title: As Fighting Rages, Ukraine Takes Its Battle to the Diplomatic Arena
item.description: A forum in Malta was intended to encourage countries that have taken a neutral stance on the invasion of Ukraine not to side with Russia.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Clearing debris from a heavily damaged firehouse in Izium, Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: Netanyahu Apologizes for Blaming Israeli Officials in Hamas Attack
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who has not taken responsibility for Israel’s lapses in the Oct. 7 massacre, deleted a social media post in which he had pointed a finger at security agencies.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Abir Sultan
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, left, with Defense Minister Yoav Gallant and Benny Gantz, a member of Israel’s war cabinet, at a news conference in Tel Aviv on Saturday.

item.title: A New Place to Learn Civics: The Workplace
item.description: Fearing that rising distrust could spell doom for businesses, some companies are offering employees lessons in democracy.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Ingmar Nolting for The New York Times
item.media:description: Susann Planert, left, a personnel policy specialist at Leipziger Gruppe, and Kerstin Schultheiss, managing director. Managers at the company said they noticed increasing tensions among employees.

item.title: A Less Polarized Poland? Not Yet, Election Results Suggest.
item.description: On whatever side they stand, many voters say they yearn for a more united nation. But after a brutal campaign, divisions — between left and right, urban and rural, young and old — remain stark.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Election posters for Law and Justice near the church in Drozdowo, eastern Poland. Most villages and small towns voted heavily for nationalist forces.

item.title: Israel’s Hidden Victims, Arab Bedouins, Were Attacked by Hamas Too
item.description: At least 17 died in the Hamas attacks, and many more in the impoverished community have since lost their livelihoods in Jewish farms that were ransacked.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman and Gal Koplewitz
item.media:credit: Yuri Cortez/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Members of the Bedouin community in the village of Arara, southern Israel, after a rocket strike.

item.title: Pro-Palestine Protesters in NYC March Onto Brooklyn Bridge
item.description: A large demonstration crossed the Brooklyn Bridge a day after Israel pushed into Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Erin Nolan, Eliza Fawcett and Nate Schweber
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters cross the Brooklyn Bridge Saturday as they demonstrate against the continuing Israeli military assault on Gaza.

item.title: Vatican Deems Bigger Role for Women ‘Urgent’ but Punts on Major Issues
item.description: Progressives who once hoped that the synod would create momentum for things like reaching out to L.G.B.T.Q.+ Catholics said the meeting had failed to move the institution.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Alessandra Tarantino/Associated Press
item.media:description: Pope Francis convened a monthlong meeting of more than 400 clerics, nuns and laypeople that aimed to consider the future of the Roman Catholic Church.

item.title: Israel-Hamas War Enters ‘Second Stage,’ Netanyahu Says
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel did not describe the ground incursion as an invasion, but it was accompanied by an enormous aerial and artillery bombardment.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Ronen Bergman and Thomas Fuller
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli armored vehicles near the border with Gaza on Saturday.

item.title: Israeli Approach to Ground War in Gaza Aligns with U.S. Advice, Officials Say
item.description: The initial decision to undertake limited ground incursions rather than a full-scale invasion appears to follow guidance from top U.S. military officials.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli armored vehicles near the border with southern Gaza on Saturday.

item.title: At Least 32 Killed in Vehicle Collision in Egypt
item.description: Several cars caught fire after a passenger bus and several vehicles collided on a main road north of Cairo, injuring more than 60 other people, state media reported.
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.media:credit: EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Several vehicles and a passenger bus collided north of Cairo on Saturday. The police said an oil leak had caused the crash.

item.title: Israel Says Al Shifa Hospital Conceals Hamas Underground Command Centers
item.description: The group denies the accusation, saying Israel has offered “fabricated” evidence.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Mohammed Saber/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The Al Shifa Hospital lit up in Gaza City on Tuesday.

item.title: Gaza Residents Describe Israeli Airstrikes: ‘You Think of Dying at Any Time’
item.description: Gaza residents say Israeli airstrikes come mostly without warning and hit indiscriminately, leading to the feeling that death is imminent and inevitable.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olfat al-Kurd with her family at a displacement camp in Khan Younis in southern Gaza on Thursday.

item.title: Armita Geravand, Iranian Teen Who Collapsed on Subway, Dies From Injuries
item.description: The death of Armita Geravand comes after word of her injuries fueled outrage because she was so young and because of previous cases in which women have been brutalized for protesting dress codes.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Iranian State Television, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Station footage showing Armita Geravand being dragged out of a subway car in Tehran this month.

item.title: Russia’s Former Pick to Be Ukraine’s Puppet Leader Is Shot in Crimea
item.description: Oleg Tsaryov, a pro-Russian businessman and former lawmaker, was said to have been wounded in the attack. Moscow had planned to set him up as head of government in Kyiv if its invasion had succeeded.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oleg Tsaryov in 2014.

item.title: Days After Hurricane Otis, a Desperate Search for Food and Water in Mexico
item.description: Days after the storm, the death toll rose to 39 and residents were navigating broken glass, searching for water and food, and trying to find loved ones. Many said the government was not doing enough.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Elda Cantú
item.media:credit: Getty Images/Getty Images
item.media:description: Hurricane-damaged buildings in Acapulco, Mexico, on Thursday.
